author: By Alex Williams
title: Irma Capece Minutolo, Opera Singer and Partner to Exiled King, Dies at 87
description: The former Naples beauty queen became famous as the companion to the playboy Farouk I of Egypt, then carved out a successful opera career.
content: Irma Capece Minutolo, a Neapolitan beauty queen and opera singer whose relationship with the exiled Egyptian king and world-renowned hedonist, Farouk I, became fodder for gossip columnists around the world, died on June 7 at her home in Rome. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Cadejo Blanco’ Review: Negotiating Guatemalan Street Life
description: In this film a young woman searching for her missing sister infiltrates a gang, but the focus is diffuse and the promised thriller never materializes.
content: The description of “Cadejo Blanco,” directed by Justin Lerner, reads like a thriller: After her sister disappears, a young Guatemalan woman infiltrates a gang to try to find her. But there are few thrills in the film, which moves slowly and with too much ease through the world of Guatemalan gangs. It’s beautifully shot and gives an authentic view of street life there, but the characters’ journeys are not sufficiently developed, and the resolutions feel unearned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: In Miami, the Only Violence From Trump Supporters Was Rhetorical
description: Calls for retribution were plentiful after the former president’s indictments, but the demonstrations proved tame, a possible result of the aggressive prosecution of the Jan. 6 rioters.
content: Twice in recent months, allies of former President Donald J. Trump have used violent language to criticize the criminal charges brought against him, calling for vengeance and encouraging Mr. Trump’s supporters to respond to the indictments as though they were acts of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Best for Bird-Watching and Good for Rats, Too: No Place Like New York
description: The city is one of the rattiest, least affordable and most bike-friendly municipalities anywhere. Also, the return of the dreaded spotted lanternfly.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll revisit what surveys say about New York and how they shape perceptions of the city. We’ll also see why the spotted lanternfly is not your friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Surfside Condo’s Pool Deck Had ‘Severe Strength Deficiency,’ Investigators Say
description: Federal investigators released preliminary findings on the 13-story tower’s collapse in Florida but say more work is needed to determine what led to 98 deaths.
content: The condo in Surfside, Fla., that collapsed two years ago had a “severe strength deficiency” in its pool deck, with a design that failed to meet building codes and construction that did not follow its original plans, federal investigators said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Jan Hoffman
title: Indigenous Leaders Elated by Supreme Court Ruling on Adoptions
description: The decision on Thursday bolsters Indigenous sovereignty by upholding a 1978 law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes.
content: Maryanna Harstad was stunned and then elated when she heard that the Supreme Court had upheld a law on Thursday aimed at keeping Native American adoptees with their tribes and traditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Good Luck, and Bad, on New York’s Sidewalks
description: Felix Morelo’s chalk circles give parks, paths and pavements a burst of spiritual energy.
content: If you find yourself in Washington Square Park on one of these fine spring days, you might see Felix Morelo, bent low over the sidewalk, drawing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Blackening’ Review: Race Against a Killer
description: With more jokes than jump scares, this comedic horror film is as tartly amusing as it is provocative.
content: There are two games at play in “The Blackening,” a comedic horror film with more jokes than jump scares. The first is the titular race-baiting board game with the grotesque Jim Crow-style figurine that Morgan (Yvonne Orji) and her boyfriend, Shawn (Jay Pharoah), discover as they explore the cabin they have rented for a reunion of college friends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 20 Great Queer Y.A. Books to Add to Your Reading List
description: These stories — heartfelt family sagas, thrillers and everything in between — dive into the beauty, challenges and complexity of being queer today.
content: Looking to dive into a new queer young adult novel? We’ve got you covered! We asked 20 authors of queer Y.A. literature to recommend a queer Y.A. book that they love. The responses ranged from heartfelt family stories to electrifying thrillers, and everything in between. The one thing they have in common, though, is they all explore the beauty, challenges and complexity of being queer today. That means, no matter what kind of reader you are, we’ve got a recommendation for you. So without further ado, here are 20 queer Y.A. books to add to your reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: I Won’t Let Donald Trump Invade My Brain
description: How to stay sane during the coming presidential campaign.
content: I try to be a reasonable person. I try to be someone who looks out on the world with trusting eyes. Over the decades, I’ve built up certain expectations about how the world works and how people behave. I rely on those expectations as I do my job, analyzing events and anticipating what will happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Cooking With a Dirty Pan
description: A cut corner leads to contaminated steak skewers. Who’s at fault?
content: Mike writes: I roasted some steak skewers on a baking pan, which was still dirty from last night’s roasted squash. I deemed it fine to use again. After dinner, my wife said, “I hope you washed that pan.” She had sprayed chemical degreaser on it to soak overnight. Who’s at fault here?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: The Great Bob Thompson, in Two Parts
description: A big retrospective bypassed New York recently but two gallery exhibitions, at 52 Walker and Michael Rosenfeld, more than make up for it.
content: Few painters have used color as vigorously or as variously as Bob Thompson, the remarkable, driven American artist who was born in Louisville, Ky., in 1937, and died in Rome on the brink of his 29th birthday in 1966, worn down by ill health, substance abuse and a seemingly relentless work ethic. But Thompson never doubted his talent and had a voracious appetite for culture in many forms: He consorted with New York’s Beat poets and its free jazz musicians as well as a broad range of artists. His career lasted barely eight years, but he left behind several hundred paintings, drawings and oil studies — a fabulous horde whose magnitude is still not well known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Hey Dad, Can You Help Me Return the Picasso I Stole?
description: A painting that went missing in 1969 turned up at a museum’s doorstep before the F.B.I. could hunt it down. No one knew how or why — until now.
content: The Picasso fell off the proverbial truck. It vanished from a loading dock at Logan International Airport in Boston and wound up where it didn’t belong, in the modest home of one Merrill Rummel, also known as Bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Amanda Holpuch
title: Starbucks Is Under Scrutiny Over Removal of Pride Decorations
description: The union Starbucks Workers United says the chain, after prominently celebrating Pride for years, has banned the displays. The company insists that’s not true and said the examples are an “outlier.”
content: A union representing hundreds of Starbucks stores said this week that workers in 21 states were told by their managers not to decorate for Pride Month, the annual L.G.B.T.Q. celebration, a claim that the company said represented “outlier” decisions by local leaders that did not reflect corporate policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Charged With Killing Mother at Sea in Inheritance Scheme Dies in Jail
description: Nathan Carman, 29, of Vernon, Vt., was to go on trial on murder charges in October. He had pleaded not guilty.
content: A Vermont man died in jail on Thursday morning while awaiting trial on federal charges that he had lured his mother on a fishing trip, killed her and sank the boat in a scheme to inherit his family’s estate, the U.S. Marshals Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Jakeman
title: Test Cricket’s Last Stand
description: The Ashes, a century-old rivalry between England and Australia, is the most venerable showcase for a version of cricket that is losing ground to faster, richer rivals.
content: Not many international sporting contests predate the countries that play them, but few contests are as old as the Ashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: A Fashion Designer’s Classic Milanese Aperitivo
description: Damir Doma toasted his latest collection with his creative friends and collaborators.
content: In Milan, there’s one unofficial but very important entertaining rule: Never throw a party on a Saturday night. Monday through Friday, the city is brimming with creative people — the quiet engines running the design and fashion industries — but, when the weekend rolls around, they tend to leave for the nearby Swiss Alps or the Mediterranean coast. Weekdays are when the Milanese gather and the aperitivo, a postwork, pre-dinner cocktail hour, defines the city’s social life. “The Milanese are very busy,” says the fashion designer Damir Doma, 42, a native of Croatia who was raised in Germany and has been living in the northern Italian city since 2016. “Aperitivo brings everyone together for a short moment to have a drink and a chat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Akerman
title: Don’t Automatically Write Off the Judge in the Trump Documents Case
description: Aileen Cannon has the credentials needed to oversee the case.
content: Judge Aileen Cannon, randomly assigned to preside over the prosecution of Donald Trump in the classified document case, is coming under intensely critical scrutiny from the left. Some point out that she was appointed to her position by Mr. Trump. Others highlight her actions last year, when she disrupted the documents investigation by issuing rulings favorable to him when he challenged the F.B.I.’s search of his Mar-a-Lago resort — before an appeals court ruled that she never had legal authority to intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Terris
title: Why Did Washington Fall So Hard for the Bankman-Fried Brothers?
description: Sam and Gabe Bankman-Fried became major players in Washington and disappeared from the scene shockingly fast. Why (besides a lot of money)?
content: Before everything fell apart, Gabe Bankman-Fried believed he had a superpower that could help him deal with Washington’s many blowhards and suck-ups. He possessed, he said, a sort of X-ray vision that allowed him to see a person’s true character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Penguins in Your Fridge? These 7-Year-Olds Have Climate Solutions.
description: New Jersey is the first state to require that climate change be taught at all grade levels. The focus is on problem solving, not doom and gloom.
content: Standing at the front of her classroom at Slackwood Elementary School north of Trenton, N.J., one afternoon in June, Michelle Liwacz asked her first graders to consider a problem: Antarctica is getting warmer. What could the penguins that live there do to adapt?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: How G.O.P. Rivals View Trump’s Indictment, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Ebony G. Patterson Brings a Crowd to the New York Botanical Garden
description: All that glitters isn’t what you expect at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. The vultures have landed.
content: I have to admit, I didn’t notice them at first. They blend seamlessly as shadows into the bright red petunias and purple coleus on the lawn of the New York Botanical Garden’s Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. Only when I stooped to read the label for one velvety red blossom — it was a cockscomb, Celosia “Dracula” — did I notice the knee-high, cast-foam black vulture that was sitting watchfully beside it. When I looked up, I realized there were dozens more. The gardens were full of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: It’s Not Just You: Many Americans Face Insurance Obstacles Over Medical Care and Bills
description: A new survey indicates that a majority of U.S. adults who are insured have experienced a raft of problems including troubles with access to medical care and unexpected, higher bills.
content: A majority of Americans with health insurance said they had encountered obstacles to coverage, including denied medical care, higher bills and a dearth of doctors in their plans, according to a new survey from KFF, a nonprofit health research group. As a result, some people delayed or skipped treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The White House Renews Its Attack on ‘Surprise Fees’
description: President Biden will host executives from several companies, including Airbnb and Live Nation, to announce new efforts to end so-called junk fees as inflation remains high.
content: With inflation still a potent political issue, President Biden is stepping up his war on so-called junk fees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
title: The Radical Strategy Behind Trump’s Promise to ‘Go After’ Biden
description: Conservatives with close ties to Donald J. Trump are laying out a “paradigm-shifting” legal rationale to erase the Justice Department’s independence from the president.
content: When Donald J. Trump responded to his latest indictment by promising to appoint a special prosecutor if he’s re-elected to “go after” President Biden and his family, he signaled that a second Trump term would fully jettison the post-Watergate norm of Justice Department independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Horace Tapscott Was a Force in L.A. Jazz. A New Set May Expand His Reach.
description: “60 Years,” a compilation marking the 60th anniversary of his Pan Afrikan Peoples Arkestra, spotlights the pianist and community organizer, who died in 1999.
content: There’s a name engraved in the sidewalk along Degnan Boulevard in Los Angeles’ Leimert Park neighborhood: Horace Tapscott, the local pianist and organizer whose ensemble, the Pan Afrikan Peoples Arkestra, gave many musicians their first gigs and helped heal a community impacted by racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Medical Group Says B.M.I. Alone Is Not Enough to Assess Health and Weight
description: Body mass index has long been a standard, but controversial, measurement of weight and health.
content: The American Medical Association voted to adopt a new policy on Tuesday encouraging doctors not to rely only on body mass index, a long-used but potentially misleading metric, when assessing weight and health. The policy officially recognizes the “historical harm” of B.M.I. and states that the metric has been used “for racist exclusion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ukraine Is Finding It ‘Very Difficult to Advance’
description: Also, a victory for Native American tribes. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: After a string of notable early successes, progress has slowed in Ukraine’s counteroffensive to retake land occupied by Russian forces. For a third straight day, Ukraine did not claim to have retaken any settlements, and independent analysts say that recent Ukrainian advances in the southeast, where Kyiv began a multipronged assault last week, are better measured in yards than miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Jury Weighs Case of Men Accused of Stalking U.S. Residents for China
description: During a two-week trial, prosecutors made their case that an American private detective, Michael McMahon, and two Chinese citizens did Beijing’s dirty work.
content: A jury is considering the case of a former New York Police Department sergeant and two other men accused of stalking a family in New Jersey on behalf of the Chinese government after their two-week trial wrapped up in Brooklyn federal court on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: This May Not Take as Long as You Think It Will
description: It feels as if our digital technology is gaslighting us.
content: This column will take you five minutes, according to the New York Times website, which now posts an estimated reading time for articles on its home page. You can easily finish it while waiting for your DoorDash, which will arrive in 12 minutes, shortly after your laundry cycle ends in — check the app — seven minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump and the Fun Factor
description: How his legal challenges play into his reputation as an entertainer.
content: When Donald Trump was indicted on criminal charges in New York City two months ago, I tried to make sense of the political fallout with my colleague Nate Cohn, The Times’s chief political analyst. After poring over traditional markers about fund-raising and poll numbers, Nate mentioned another standard I’ve been thinking about over the past few days: Do Trump’s legal challenges make him more (or less) fun?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Neil Gorsuch Is a Committed Defender of Tribal Rights
description: In soaring opinions steeped in history, Justice Gorsuch has demonstrated a distinctive dedication to Native American rights.
content: In a pair of opinions on Thursday, Justice Neil M. Gorsuch again demonstrated that he is the fiercest proponent of Native American rights on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Our Golf Reporter Didn’t See the PGA Tour-LIV Golf Deal Coming, Either
description: The announced deal to drastically change golf took nearly everyone by surprise.
content: Alan Blinder’s plans blew up around 10 a.m. last Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Nina Feldman, Alex Stern, Michael Simon Johnson, Rob Szypko, Shannon Lin, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Marc Georges, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How Saudi Arabia Took on Pro Golf — and Won
description: The surprise merging of golf’s rival circuits is expected to transform the sport.
content: Last week, golf’s premier circuit, the PGA Tour, announced it was partnering with its rival circuit LIV Golf, an upstart league backed by Saudi Arabia, giving the country a powerful new seat at the table of international sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Oregon Town’s Marijuana Boom Yields Envy in Idaho
description: Tax revenue has surged since cannabis stores opened in Ontario, Ore., fueling a push in neighboring Idaho to legalize sales and get in on the action.
content: For John Leeds, the hour-and-a-half commute to and from his job as assistant manager at Treasure Valley Cannabis Company is exhausting, but logistically unavoidable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Ernesto Londoño
title: Canadian Wildfire Smoke Descends in an Unhealthy Haze Over Minnesota
description: Air quality reached unhealthy levels in Minneapolis and much of the state on Wednesday as smoke from the fires once again drifted into the United States.
content: As a gray cloud and a pungent smell moved through the Twin Cities on Wednesday, normally bustling bike lanes and running trails were largely deserted. Several commuters wore high-quality masks as they made their way home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Judge Cannon Preside Fairly Over the Trump Trial?
description: Readers discuss questions raised about her experience and possible bias. Also: Elizabeth Gilbert’s novel; “doing the work”; honorifics; “above the law.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Rebecca Carballo
title: Five Meerkats Mysteriously Die at the Philadelphia Zoo
description: Zoo officials suspect that a marking dye caused the deaths, but they said it could take weeks for tests results to confirm.
content: The sudden deaths of five meerkats at the Philadelphia Zoo this month have stunned zookeepers and officials, and a dye used to mark the animals might be to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Nobody’s Hero’ Review: Little Desires Everywhere
description: In this slippery farce, a schlubby coder falls in love with a prostitute and takes in a teenager he suspects is a terrorist.
content: In the first few minutes of Alain Guiraudie’s meandering farce, “Nobody’s Hero,” Médéric (Jean-Charles Clichet) spots a middle-aged woman across the street and immediately declares his love. Contrary to cliché, the gesture is not romantic but droll and startlingly arbitrary — it’s early in the morning, and the two are at an empty suburban intersection. When the lucky lady, Isadora (Noémie Lvovsky), reveals she’s a prostitute, Médéric is unfazed, even after it turns out she’s also married to her pimp, Gérard (Renaud Rutten), an oddly jealous brute who resembles Dennis Hopper in “Blue Velvet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Four Killer Whales Are Spotted Off New England Coast
description: New England Aquarium scientists captured the remarkable sight in photographs on the same day that a fishing crew saw a killer whale in the waters off Cape Cod.
content: After nearly seven hours on a plane on Sunday, two New England Aquarium research scientists had hit a lull in their search for marine mammals in the waters south of Nantucket and Martha’s Vineyard. They thought their day was almost done when one of them saw some splashing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Happer’s Comet’ Review: We Live by Night
description: The writer-director Tyler Taormina shot this highly experimental feature, which mostly takes place after dark, during the most restrictive phase of the pandemic.
content: Except in its final shot, “Happer’s Comet” takes place entirely at night. But if it weren’t for occasional glimpses of clocks, discerning the precise time would be tricky. There are plenty of people out and about, performing quiet, personal, often inexplicable tasks in an unidentified pocket of suburbia. (The film was largely shot in Smithtown, Long Island.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: How A.I. Is Helping Architects Change Workplace Design
description: With more hybrid workers and new office needs, firms like Zaha Hadid Architects are turning to artificial intelligence for solutions.
content: “I’ve been a workplace designer for the last 24 years,” said the architect Arjun Kaicker. “I’ve seen more change in the last 24 months than in the whole of my career.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Webster Ayuso
title: In Barcelona, City of Mega-Festivals, Small Venues Struggle
description: Thousands of visitors flock to the city for events like Sónar and Primavera Sound. But complaints from locals about noise and overcrowding create tough conditions for local acts.
content: On a recent Friday night, a few dozen 20-somethings piled into Sidecar, a well-known concert venue in downtown Barcelona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Mike Ives
title: Tornado Kills 3 in Texas and Injures Dozens
description: The tornado destroyed a trailer park as it pummeled the Texas Panhandle city of Perryton. At least 75 people were injured, the authorities said.
content: A storm system that swept through Texas on Thursday evening killed three people and injured dozens of others, an official said, as the state braced for a weekend of brutal heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Congress Ended Pandemic Cash for Parents, but Some States Have Embraced the Idea
description: Colorado joins a growing list of states with bipartisan support for  child tax credits, which give parents money, no strings attached.
content: For a brief period during the coronavirus pandemic, the federal government gave most parents monthly cash — up to $300 per child — with no work requirements or restrictions on how the money could be spent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Smoke From Canada Wildfires Is Returning to New York
description: The smoke is expected to be thickest on Friday morning, but forecasters said the region would be spared the orange haze that settled last week.
content: A week after a thick plume of smoke choked the air in New York City, delaying flights, closing schools and sending people to hospitals with respiratory issues, another round of eastward winds is pushing Canadian wildfire smoke toward the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Alan Feuer and Michael S. Schmidt
title: At the Heart of the Documents Case: Trump’s Attachment to His Boxes
description: The former president has long stowed papers and odds and ends in cartons that he liked to keep close. His aides have called it the “beautiful mind” material.
content: During President Donald J. Trump’s years in the White House, his aides began to refer to the boxes full of papers and odds and ends he carted around with him almost everywhere as the “beautiful mind” material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: What a Long, Strange Few Years it Was for Weddings. Bring on the Joy.
description: After years of tamped-down celebrations, some couples are embracing the glimmering, gaudy energy of the ’70s, from the Dead to disco.
content: Beyoncé’s disco-inspired “Renaissance” album. Amazon Prime’s “Daisy Jones & The Six” set in the rollicking landscape of Sunset Strip in 1977. Dead & Company’s final tour this summer. Bell-bottoms, maximalist design and plenty of marijuana. It can seem like the ’70s are everywhere again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘A Simulacrum’ Review: A Magic Show in the Making, and Unmaking
description: The magician Steve Cuiffo and the playwright Lucas Hnath try to find the reality beneath the illusions in this Atlantic Theater Company production.
content: Magicians often get a bad rap. After all, it’s a profession necessarily defined by deception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: At Least 15 Die in Highway Crash in Canada
description: A bus and a semitruck collided on a rural stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway in Manitoba on Thursday, the police said.
content: At least 15 people were killed in a crash along the Trans-Canada Highway near Carberry, Manitoba, on Thursday afternoon, after a bus carrying 25 people, mostly older people, collided with a semitruck, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Fires 2 Ballistic Missiles
description: The launch of the short-range projectiles came the same day the United States and South Korean militaries conducted a joint live-fire drill.
content: North Korea launched two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Thursday, its first missile test in two months, as the United States and South Korean militaries conducted a joint live-fire exercise near the inter-Korean border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: European Central Bank Raises Rates to Highest Level Since 2001
description: Inflation is “projected to remain too high for too long,” the central bank said as it raised interest rates by a quarter point, and signaled more increases may be coming.
content: The European Central Bank raised interest rates to their highest level in more than two decades on Thursday and warned that there was further to go in order to stamp out inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: NATO defense chiefs vow to stand by Ukraine, pledging more air defenses and training for fighter pilots.
description: U.S. officials urge patience, describing a long, bloody, difficult fight.
content: NATO allies and others meeting in Brussels on Thursday vowed to keep up their support for Ukraine indefinitely as Kyiv makes slow progress in its push to take back Russian territory, with a special emphasis on providing air defenses and ammunition and stepping up F-16 fighter jet training.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Fashion’s Reluctant It Boy
description: Eli Russell Linnetz has worked with Ye, Gaga, Dior and Comme des Garçons. What makes the siloed storyteller of Venice Beach so in demand?
content: About two months ago, Eli Russell Linnetz moved into a house built in the mid-1980s by the actor Dennis Hopper. Mr. Linnetz had spent the last few years as a kind of Venice Beach Goldilocks, moving until he found a studio that felt just right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “The Righteous Gemstones” is back. Otherwise, check out a great new cabaret special or a joyful show about bird watching.
content: ‘The Righteous Gemstones’When to watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on HBO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘That’s My Cue!’
description: David Harris tells us that there’s no place like home.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our recommended fiction this week includes a couple of story collections from writers who have long deserved wider recognition — the late Canadian author and musician Steven Heighton, who died last year at 60, and the playfully speculative writer Kelly Link, whose new book offers skewed riffs on traditional fairy tales. Also up: a satire of the publishing world, an ensemble portrait of young adulthood in Iowa City and a debut novel about a British transplant to Berlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: Gen Z-ers Are Moving Out. Where Are They Looking to Buy Homes?
description: A new study suggests that young buyers are most prevalent in smaller cities. But they’re on their way to greater market share.
content: After the pandemic forced many young adults to move back in with their parents, a new study suggests that they’re ready to test the housing market again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Watch Out for ‘Junk’ Fees When Booking Travel Online
description: Hotels and airlines struggling to recoup their losses from the pandemic have been including more hidden charges. Don’t fall for them.
content: Many of us are desperate to travel this summer after a pandemic stifled our plans for years. But travelers — and I’m sorry to be a killjoy — should beware: Those seemingly cheap plane tickets or hotel rooms advertised online may be a trap to make you spend more than anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Sudden Inquiry May Derail Thailand’s Leading Prime Minister Candidate
description: Activists say the case against the candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, is part of a broader effort to nullify election results and further erode democracy in Thailand.
content: Thailand’s Election Commission has announced that it will investigate Pita Limjaroenrat, the front-runner in the May general election, to determine whether he violated election rules that would disqualify him from becoming the country’s next prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Run-Up' Team
title: The Democrat Saying What Others Won’t
description: We speak to Julian Castro, a former challenger and early skeptic of Joe Biden, about the concerns that so many voters have. But, the Democratic Party is unwilling to engage.
content: Back in 2020, Joe Biden stood out in a crowded Democratic primary field filled with younger, more historic candidates. Voters worried that Mr. Biden was too moderate, too uninspiring and too old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Dips for Dinner
description: With an assortment of colorful vegetables, fluffy breads and crunchy crackers, any dip can become a vibrant meal.
content: There is a food-related bit on the Hulu series “Only Murders in the Building” that I think of often. It begins in the show’s second episode: At an apartment-lobby memorial for a deceased neighbor, the debt-stricken Oliver Putnam, played by the incomparable Martin Short, rushes to a table of free goodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Extraction 2’ Review: No Escape
description: Chris Hemsworth returns as an Australian mercenary in this bloated, banal action sequel.
content: “Extraction 2,” a drab, brawny sequel starring Chris Hemsworth as an Australian mercenary, offers a turgid shadow of the type of crowd-pleasing escapism that action blockbusters used to provide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Nine Women Accuse Bill Cosby of Sexual Assault in Nevada
description: The entertainer, who was released from prison in 2021 after a conviction was overturned, now faces lawsuits in states where the statutes of limitations have changed.
content: Nine women accused Bill Cosby of sexual assault in a Nevada lawsuit on Wednesday, less than two months after the state changed its statute of limitations for civil cases involving that crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Upholds Native American Adoption Law
description: At issue in the case was whether a law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes is constitutional.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a 1978 law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees with their tribes and traditions, handing a victory to tribes that had argued that a blow to the law would upend the basic principles that have allowed them to govern themselves for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence Blanchard
title: I Am Not Who You Want Me to Be
description: If you think you can define a musician’s identity only by his past work, listen again.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Elemental’ Review: Sparks Fly
description: The latest movie from Disney/Pixar tucks a romantic comedy inside a high-concept premise. It’s smoldering and splashy.
content: “Elemental” is the latest Pixar premise to feel like someone laced the cafeteria’s kombucha keg with ayahuasca. Starting eight years ago with “Inside Out,” the animation company has transformed cartoons into a form of group therapy that encourages audiences to ruminate on inner peace, death (“Coco”) and resurrection (“Soul”). This story is simpler (elemental, even). It’s a girl-meets-boy cross-cultural romantic comedy — a good one that woos us to root for the big kiss. But the Pixar-brand psychotropic flourish comes from which cultures. Here, they are water, earth, air and fire — the four classical elements that the ancient philosopher Empedocles used to explain our world — all tenuously coexisting in Element City, a Manhattan analogue founded by the first droplet to ooze out of the primordial sea. The girl, Ember Lumen (voiced by Leah Lewis), is a leggy lick of flame; her crush, Wade Ripple (Mamoudou Athie), is a drip. When she brushes near him, his body roils. Steamy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Debt Deal Behind Them, Lawmakers Plunge Into Bitter Spending Fight
description: House Republicans are pushing to pass measures with spending levels below those agreed to in the debt limit compromise, infuriating Democrats and raising the prospect of a shutdown this fall.
content: After narrowly avoiding a federal default, the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-led Senate are now on a collision course over spending that could result in a government shutdown this year and automatic spending cuts in early 2025 with severe consequences for the Pentagon and an array of domestic programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘The Doctor,’ a Rare Case of Physician, Harm Thyself
description: Robert Icke’s surgery on a 1922 play about the disease of antisemitism turns it into a riveting debate about identity. But at what cost to the patient?
content: After attempting an abortion at home, a 14-year-old girl lies dying of sepsis at the Elizabeth Institute. No one questions her treatment there; by the time she was admitted, it was too late to save her. But when Ruth Wolff, the Institute’s head doctor, refuses to let a priest perform last rites because it would cause “an unpeaceful death,” ignorance amplified by social media turns a medical decision into a maelstrom. Soon the web is saying Wolff assaulted the priest and killed the girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Glenn Thrush and Ernesto Londoño
title: Justice Dept. to Release Minneapolis Police Review After George Floyd Murder
description: The investigation was launched after Mr. Floyd was murdered during an arrest in 2020, touching off protests nationwide.
content: The Justice Department is expected to announce the results of an investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department on Friday, according to two people familiar with the planning, capping a multiyear examination of the long-troubled agency, whose abuses captured global attention when an officer murdered George Floyd in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Stay Calm During a Bumpy Flight
description: Even the most seasoned travelers can get a little anxious when the plane starts shaking.
content: On a recent flight to Chicago, Allison Levy said she was “white-knuckling” the armrest as the plane rumbled and shook for brief periods of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Brutal Killing of Governor Heralds New Round of Violence in Darfur
description: The United Nations blamed Sudanese paramilitaries for the death of the governor of West Darfur, Khamis Abdullah Abakar. Sudan’s war has destabilized a fragile western region devastated by genocide in the early 2000s.
content: The killing of a powerful governor in Darfur, in western Sudan, has heightened worries that fighting between the country’s warring military factions is pushing a region blighted by genocide two decades ago into a new ethnic civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Border Agency Medical Officer Reassigned After Child’s Death in Officials’ Custody
description: Customs and Border Protection has removed its chief medical officer from his position after an 8-year-old girl died in the agency’s custody last month.
content: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has removed its chief medical officer from his position after an 8-year-old girl died in the agency’s custody last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Ocean Warmth Set a Record for May
description: North and South America had their warmest Mays on record, as the heat contributed to wildfires and posed risks to people and wildlife.
content: Temperatures are already breaking records this year: Last month was the warmest May for the world’s oceans since record-keeping began in 1850, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: As Ties to China Turn Toxic, Even Chinese Companies Are Breaking Them
description: Companies are moving headquarters and factories outside the country and cleaving off their Chinese businesses. It’s not clear the strategy will work.
content: As it expanded internationally, Shein, the rapidly growing fast fashion app, progressively cut ties to its home country, China. It moved its headquarters to Singapore and de-registered its original company in Nanjing. It set up operations in Ireland and Indiana, and hired Washington lobbyists to highlight its U.S. expansion plans as it prepares for a potential initial public offering this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Silberner
title: How a Toilet Plunger Improved CPR
description: The conventional method for chest compressions doesn’t have a great success rate. Doctors are pumping it up with a high-tech plunger.
content: In 1988, a 65-year-old man’s heart stopped at home. His wife and son didn’t know CPR, so in desperation they grabbed a toilet plunger to get his heart going until an ambulance showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Jon Moss
title: Jurors Begin Deliberations in First Phase of Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial
description: If the jury finds Robert Bowers guilty of carrying out the 2018 massacre, the panel will weigh whether he should be sentenced to death.
content: After three weeks of wrenching testimony, the prosecution and the defense delivered closing arguments on Thursday in the first phase of the federal trial of the man charged with carrying out the deadliest antisemitic attack in the country’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published Visual Books, From Asylum Seekers to Ruth E. Carter
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: ASYLUM, by Umberto Nicola Nicoletti. (Rizzoli, $80.) Nicoletti captures the dignity and pain of L.G.B.T.Q. asylum seekers in these glossy monochrome portraits, accompanied by searing anonymous testimonies drawn from their letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Ossining, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in New Canaan, Conn.
content: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 2,408-square-foot, recently renovated 1940 house with a slate front porch, three fireplaces (one electric), a formal living room, a sunroom/office, an open kitchen/dining area with center-island seating, en suite bedrooms with custom closets, central air-conditioning, a lower level, a side brick patio, a lawn and a two-car garage, on 0.48 acres. Eric Schatz, Schatz Realty Group, 914-274-7021; schatzrealtors.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ware
title: ‘Menace II Society’ at 30: A Bleak Nightmare Then, a Milestone Now
description: With a tragic hero at its heart, the Hughes brothers’ debut drama painted nuanced portraits of characters rarely fleshed out in other films.
content: When it was released 30 years ago, “Menace II Society” was a shock to the system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Twomey
title: Frozen Strawberries Are Recalled After Hepatitis A Infections
description: The F.D.A. urges checking freezers for the affected products sold at Walmart, Costco, Trader Joe’s and other retailers.
content: A voluntary recall of frozen strawberries has been expanded as the Food and Drug Administration has linked more retailers to a string of nine hepatitis A cases that date back to last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Dumitrescu
title: How Do Certain Foods Become National Dishes?
description: A new book digs into the histories of some of the world’s most iconic fare.
content: “We have a compulsion to tie food to place,” Anya von Bremzen writes in her new book, but that compulsion, it turns out, has more to do with myth and marketing than with historical fact. “National Dish” is the story of her quest to understand why certain foods, like pizza, ramen and tapas, are adopted as symbols of their places of origin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: West Coast Dockworkers Reach Contract Deal With Port Operators
description: After a year of prolonged negotiations that have led to delays and declines in cargo, the two sides agreed to a new contract with help from the Biden administration.
content: After a year of contract negotiations that resulted in numerous delays and a decline in the movement of cargo at ports along the West Coast, union dockworkers and port operators have reached a tentative deal set to last for six years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Highlights From More Than 50 Years of Glenda Jackson Reviews
description: The word that keeps recurring in more than half a century’s worth of reviews in The New York Times? Intelligence.
content: Over decades’ worth of reviews of Glenda Jackson’s work — on the stage and on screens both large and small — what struck critic after critic, above all, was her intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate Groups Back Biden Despite Broken Promises on Oil Drilling
description: Four major environmental groups are endorsing President Biden’s re-election bid, but some climate activists say his approval of drilling projects has been a betrayal.
content: Four of the country’s largest environmental organizations said they are endorsing President Biden’s bid for re-election, despite anger from activists over his approval of a string of fossil fuel projects, including an enormous oil drilling plan in Alaska and a natural gas pipeline from West Virginia through Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Ticket Giants, Under Pressure From Biden, Promise Transparency on Fees
description: Live Nation and SeatGeek said they would show customers the full cost of concerts, after the White House’s complaints that “junk fees” for tickets and hotel stays can mislead consumers.
content: Under pressure from the Biden administration, some of the biggest companies that handle ticketing for concerts and other live events announced on Thursday that they will make it easier for consumers to see the full price of tickets they want to buy, including the fees that can often add more than 30 percent to the total cost of an order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: The Instant Pot Was Beloved. Now Its Maker Has Filed for Bankruptcy.
description: Since sales surged during the pandemic, Instant Brands has struggled to find new fans for its beloved Instant Pot and other products.
content: Drop in some ground beef, onions, bell peppers, tomatoes and spices. Press a button, head out for work and return hours later to a perfectly prepared chili.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Series of Mistakes Is (Mostly) Forgotten With a Walk-Off Win
description: Brandon Nimmo’s hit in the 10th gave the struggling Mets a thrilling victory over the Yankees. It also gave his team a rare chance to relax.
content: When a struggling team scores a thrilling victory — especially in a packed ballpark against a crosstown rival before a day off — the question just has to be asked: How big was this win?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Tour Boat in Fatal Capsizing Was Unregulated and Had Tipped Before
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said her administration would look into how such waterborne tourist attractions in New York could be made safer.
content: After a tour boat capsized in a tunnellike cavern in western New York this week, killing a man and injuring nearly a dozen others, officials said they were investigating when the boat had last been inspected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Book That Changed Robert Rubin’s Thinking About Poverty
description: The former Treasury secretary, whose new book is “The Yellow Pad,” says that Ken Auletta’s “The Underclass” convinced him that “trying to break the cycle of poverty through policy and through private efforts is not just right for moral reasons, but is enormously in the interest of all.”
content: I’m always reading multiple books at the same time, switching between them depending on my interest at the moment and my mood. Right now, I have “The Congressional Journal of Barber B. Conable, Jr., 1968-1984,” “Paris 1919,” by Margaret MacMillan, which I’m rereading, and Edith Wharton’s “The Age of Innocence,” which I just finished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Hurdle
title: Uptick Seen in Red Knots on Jersey Shore
description: An annual spring count instilled hope among biologists that the threatened shorebird may be recovering from recent declines. Crab harvesting bans were partly credited for the rise.
content: The number of rufa red knot shore birds migrating via Delaware Bay beaches to Arctic breeding sites this spring rose to the highest level in four years, according to an independent annual survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney’s Chief Financial Officer Is Stepping Down
description: Christine M. McCarthy, who held the role for eight years, helped stabilize the company during the pandemic and played a key role in Bob Chapek’s ouster.
content: Christine M. McCarthy, who in her eight years as Disney’s chief financial officer helped stabilize the company during the pandemic, when most of Disney was shut down, and played a key role in the ouster of Bob Chapek as chief executive last year, will step down on July 1, she said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Steph Catudal’s Memoir Is Actually Two Books Woven Together
description: When her husband was diagnosed with lung cancer, the author was haunted by a long-ago loss — one she’d already written about.
content: Here’s a little secret about Steph Catudal’s memoir, “Everything All at Once,” which chronicles her husband’s harrowing skirmish with lung cancer in 2020: The book’s even-numbered chapters were written years ago, long before Tommy Rivers Puzey, Catudal’s ultramarathon-running spouse, developed a hacking cough that gave her a bone-chilling sense of déjà vu. It had to be Covid-19, right? Wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Rats, Summer Reads and a Virgin’s Dilemma: Audio Highlights
description: Each week, we share the best of audio journalism and storytelling from our new app.
content: This week, we went inside a courtroom where Donald Trump was indicted, again; met a man who couldn’t give up his pet rats; and found joy in running “Slow AF.” Welcome to your weekly newsletter from New York Times Audio, where app editors share their favorite listens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Nightingale
title: Glenda Jackson, Oscar-Winning Actress Turned Politician, Dies at 87
description: She walked away from a successful acting career to enter the British Parliament, before returning to the stage as the title character in an acclaimed “King Lear.”
content: Glenda Jackson, the two-time Oscar winner who renounced a successful film and stage career in her 50s to become a member of the British Parliament, then returned to the stage at 80 as the title character in “King Lear,” died on Thursday at her home in Blackheath, London. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By CAConrad and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: from ‘Listen to the Golden Boomerang Return’
description: This work about what the skeptic loses shows signature care for the visual impact of the words on the page.
content: This is a poem about what the skeptic loses — imagination, along with a necessary connection to ancient practices. How are we to believe in Earth if we can’t believe in the Heavens? In the plodding directionlessness of the present, we are lost without the astral maps. I want to point out too CAConrad’s signature care for the visual impact of the poem. The disciplined shaping means that the poetic line here not only carries sound and sentiment but builds toward a striking sculptural presence. CAConrad’s is poetry that reaches for multidimensionality, and in this poem, the arc and increment of indentation is a convincer, moving with and toward the poem’s conclusion. (This poem first appeared in Copenhagen Magazine.) Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Mayor London Breed Discusses San Francisco’s Woes and What Lies Ahead
description: San Francisco has struggled more than most American cities, and additional challenges lie ahead as employees continue to work from home.
content: San Francisco has been an outlier among American cities in its inability to rebound from pandemic lockdowns. Nearly a third of offices downtown are vacant, the highest share of any major city in the country. Stores are closing every week as employees, especially in the technology sector, continue to work from home. On Monday, the mall owner Westfield said it was abandoning the city’s largest downtown shopping mall, Westfield San Francisco Centre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece Detains 9 on Charges Amid Search for Migrants After Crowded Ship Capsizes
description: The authorities revised the toll of the deadly shipwreck down to 78. But hundreds of people were feared missing, and nine survivors were detained on criminal charges.
content: The grim search by Greek authorities for migrants after the country’s deadliest shipwreck in years moved into a second day on Thursday, though the prospects of finding survivors was slim and hundreds were feared to be missing after their fishing ship capsized about 50 miles off the coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colette Coleman
title: Black Real Estate Agent Wins Racial Bias Case Against Hamptons Firm
description: Shauncy Claud claimed that Brown Harris Stevens of the Hamptons terminated her contract after she told a supervisor that her white colleagues received more favorable treatment.
content: Brown Harris Stevens of the Hamptons, a branch of one of New York City’s oldest and most prestigious real estate firms, wrongfully terminated the contract of a Black real estate agent who raised concerns about racial discrimination there, a federal judge ruled last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Robert Mondavi Changed Wine. His Grandson Aims to Change Farming.
description: Carlo Mondavi takes on climate change by pushing regenerative and organic agriculture, with the help of a smart electric tractor.
content: Robert Mondavi paved the way for Napa Valley to take a place among the leading wine regions of the world and raised the bar for all American producers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Russian Ransomware Group Breached Federal Agencies in Cyberattack
description: The top U.S. cybersecurity agency said it did not have evidence that the group was acting in coordination with the Russian government.
content: A Russian ransomware group gained access to data from federal agencies, including the Energy Department, in an attack that exploited file transfer software to steal and sell back users’ data, U.S. officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Will Leave Hospital on Friday, Vatican Says
description: The Vatican described the pope’s recovery nine days after undergoing abdominal surgery as “regular.”
content: Pope Francis will be discharged from the hospital on Friday, according to the Vatican, nine days after the 86-year-old pontiff underwent abdominal surgery for a hernia, an unexpected operation that raised concerns about his health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Airman Who Leaked Files Is Indicted on Charges of Mishandling Secrets
description: Jack Teixeira, 21, could face up to 60 years in prison after being indicted on six counts of retaining and transmitting classified national defense information.
content: A federal grand jury on Thursday indicted Jack Teixeira, a Massachusetts Air National Guardsman who posted dozens of secret intelligence reports and other sensitive documents on a social media server, on six counts of retaining and transmitting classified national defense information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Counteroffensive Is Grueling and Costly, but Promising, Ukraine and U.S. Say
description: American and Ukrainian defense officials said the fight to dislodge dug-in Russian forces occupying southeastern Ukraine was expected to be brutal.
content: Ukraine’s counteroffensive against formidable Russian defenses has been grueling and bloody, Ukrainian and American officials acknowledged on Thursday, but they insisted that it was making gains and that any verdict on its success was extremely premature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Finance Executive Accused of Drugging and Raping Teen in Midtown Hotel
description: Michael Olson, 54, flew the girl around the country, passing her off as his daughter, prosecutors said. He kept spreadsheets of children he contacted, they said.
content: A 54-year-old finance executive targeted a 14-year-old girl through her Instagram account, passed her off as his daughter on trips around the country, gave her drugs and raped her in New York City hotel rooms, prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Homer Jones Dies at 82; Wide Receiver Specialized in Bombs and Spikes
description: For a few years with the Giants, he was among the most feared pass catchers in the N.F.L. — and the acknowledged inventor of an end-zone celebration.
content: Homer Jones, one of the greatest receivers the New York Giants have ever had and one of the fastest in the history of pro football, died on Wednesday in Pittsburg, Texas. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and Paula Vogel Are Broadway Bound
description: Second Stage, a nonprofit with a focus on living American dramatists, said it will present works by the playwrights on Broadway this season.
content: Second Stage, a nonprofit theater that focuses on work by living American writers, said it will present a well-known piece by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and a new work by Paula Vogel on Broadway this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ex-Police Officers Who Fatally Shot Man Must Be Reinstated, Arbitrators Rule
description: Arbitrators concluded that Nathan Ronan and Robert Hinkle, who are facing manslaughter charges in the 2021 killing of Quadry Sanders, were unjustifiably terminated by Lawton, Okla.
content: Two former Oklahoma police officers facing manslaughter charges in the fatal 2021 shooting of an unarmed Black man must be reinstated and receive back pay, arbitrators who reviewed their cases have ordered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.N. Nuclear Official Visits Zaporizhzhia Plant to Assess Safety
description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the head of the United Nations’ atomic agency, is investigating conditions at the plant, which is held by Russian forces.
content: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, visited the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on Thursday after the destruction of a dam in southern Ukraine that compromised a key source of water used to cool the plant’s reactors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Bipartisan Proposals Would Hit E-Commerce Like Fast Fashion
description: Critics say the law gives an unfair advantage to e-commerce companies from other countries, including some where forced labor is an issue.
content: Two bipartisan bills introduced in Congress this week aim to change a nearly 100-year-old trade rule that allows imported packages that fall under a certain price threshold to receive less oversight in the U.S. customs process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Men’s College World Series: Future Pros and Plenty of Contenders
description: Wake Forest has had the best pitching this baseball season, led by Rhett Lowder. But there are several fellow M.L.B. prospects in the championship field.
content: The 64 teams in the N.C.A.A. baseball tournament have been whittled to eight, and now it’s time for the College World Series, with a pack of future major leaguers on the field, a favorite returning after a long wait and one big long shot. Here’s what to know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: What’s a Barranca? U.S. Open Golfers Hope They Don’t Find Out.
description: The Los Angeles Country Club’s barranca, a narrow gully, winds through the course, providing drainage during rainy season and a challenge to the players.
content: Not many major golf championships have also served as an opportunity for fans to broaden their vocabulary, but this year’s U.S. Open at the Los Angeles Country Club may do just that. Across the four days of the tournament, beginning Thursday, expect broadcasters — and perhaps the golfers — to routinely use a word that may be unfamiliar to many in the international viewing audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Are the Dirtiest Beaches in California?
description: Taking a dip in polluted waters makes it more likely that you’ll develop stomach illnesses, ear infections, rashes and more.
content: Slather up with sunscreen. Grab some flip-flops, towels and maybe a book. And make sure to check your beach’s water quality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: De Blasio Owes City $475,000 for Bringing Police on Presidential Campaign
description: New York City’s Conflicts of Interest Board said the former mayor must reimburse the city for police officers’ travel, and pay a record fine.
content: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, must reimburse the city nearly $320,000 and pay a $155,000 fine for bringing his security detail on trips during his failed presidential campaign, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board ordered on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Panel Advises Vaccine Makers to Aim at Only One Covid Variant
description: An F.D.A. advisory panel told manufacturers to aim the latest coronavirus vaccine for the fall at the dominant SARS-CoV-2 variant.
content: Vaccine makers should target the XBB variant of the coronavirus in a shot to be available in the fall, moving away from the existing formula that protected against the Omicron variant and an early form of the virus, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration agreed on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: notorious
description: This word has appeared in 635 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word notorious has appeared in 635 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 18 in “To Fight Rats, N.Y.C. Restaurants Will Have to Put Trash in Containers” by Emma G. Fitzsimmons:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Maggie Moore(s)’ Review: Body Trouble
description: Tina Fey and Jon Hamm fail to invigorate this listless murder mystery about two victims who shared the same name.
content: “Some of this actually happened,” we are advised at the beginning of John Slattery’s second feature, “Maggie Moore(s).” At least it’s a variation on the groaningly familiar “based on a true story,” even if both claims are equally meaningless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Elizabeth Holmes Says She Can’t Afford $250 Payments to Theranos Victims
description: Ms. Holmes was ordered to pay $250 a month to defrauded investors after her prison term. Her lawyers said she had “limited financial resources.”
content: Lawyers for the disgraced entrepreneur Elizabeth Holmes said this week that she would be unable to afford to pay $250 each month to victims of her failed blood-testing start-up, Theranos, after leaving prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: U.S. nuclear negotiations with Iran.
content: The Biden administration has been quietly negotiating with Iran to limit its nuclear program and free imprisoned Americans, according to officials from three countries, as part of a larger U.S. effort to ease tensions and reduce the risk of a military confrontation with the Islamic country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohamed Ahmed and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenyan Cult Survivors, Still Refusing to Eat, Face Suicide Charges

title: A 40-Foot Wedding Cake in the English Countryside
description: Plus: getaways to Athens and the Philippines, portraits of queer tenderness and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: The Portuguese artist Joana Vasconcelos is known for her ambitious oversize sculptures that frequently elevate everyday objects. Her 2005 Venice Biennale contribution, “A Noiva” (The Bride), was a chandelier made of 14,000 tampons and “Valkyrie Miss Dior,” the imposing, tentacular fabric-wrapped installation that formed the backdrop of Maria Grazia Chiuri’s fall ’23 show for Dior, took over the show space at Paris’s Jardin des Tuileries. Vasconcelos’s newest project is her most ambitious yet: “Wedding Cake,” an almost 40-foot-high three-tiered wedding cake pavilion in pastel shades of pink, green and blue, was installed this spring on the grounds of Waddesdon Manor in Buckinghamshire, England. The whimsical creation is clad in 25,000 ceramic tiles (manufactured in Vasconcelos’s native Lisbon) and adorned with ceramic cherubs, dolphins and a water feature. Commissioned by the collector and arts philanthropist Lord Jacob Rothschild, the “impossible project,” as the artist describes it, has been five years in the making and is the culmination of Vasconcelos’s long-held fascination with the dynamics of weddings: “Weddings are the most important moment in some women’s lives,” she says. “It’s the transition from one identity to another. All transition moments are marked by symbols. This is my way of working through these symbols and asking if they still make sense.” “Wedding Cake” opens June 18, waddesdon.org.uk.

content: “Asteroid City,” the latest from Wes Anderson, is filled with the assiduous visuals, mythic faces and charming curiosities that you expect from this singular filmmaker. It’s comic and often wry, but like some of his other films, it has the soul of a tragedy. It’s partly set in 1955 in a fictional Southwest town, a lonely four corners with a diner, gas station and motor inn. author: By Eyal Press
title: The Moral Crisis of America’s Doctors
description: The corporatization of health care has changed the practice of medicine, causing many physicians to feel alienated from their work.
content: Some years ago, a psychiatrist named Wendy Dean read an article about a physician who died by suicide. Such deaths were distressingly common, she discovered. The suicide rate among doctors appeared to be even higher than the rate among active military members, a notion that startled Dean, who was then working as an administrator at a U.S. Army medical research center in Maryland. Dean started asking the physicians she knew how they felt about their jobs, and many of them confided that they were struggling. Some complained that they didn’t have enough time to talk to their patients because they were too busy filling out electronic medical records. Others bemoaned having to fight with insurers about whether a person with a serious illness would be preapproved for medication. The doctors Dean surveyed were deeply committed to the medical profession. But many of them were frustrated and unhappy, she sensed, not because they were burned out from working too hard but because the health care system made it so difficult to care for their patients.
